photos.description: Visiting Cabin 1
photos.source: Jean Culver's autobiography 'Recollections of My Life'
photos.notes: This was scanned from Jean's book. This is the only copy of this image.

photos.description: Friday Harbor High School's first graduating class gathers for commencement in June 1915. From left to right are (first row): George Higgins, Norman Churchill, Loretta Newhall, and Arthur Groll; (second row) Leda Culver, Louise Nelson, Albert Nash, and Richard Wotton. Most of their fathers were prominent in the town business directory.
photos.source: Scanned from 'Images of Friday America: Friday Harbor'. Authors: Mike and Julia Vouri and the San Juan Historical Society and Museum.

photos.description: At 61.5 feet long and 19.8 feet abeam, the ship was stubby in comparison with sleek Mosquito Fleet vessels such as the Rosalie. Built in Seattle in 1890, she displaced 80 tons and drew 7.1 feet of water, which enabled her to call at low tide in many harbors. After she foundered in Bellingham Bay in 1895 (one person was killed), she was raised and put into service as a ferry and charter for hire. But no one seemed leery of coming aboard again, especially not these passengers, dressed to party in derbies and dresses for a Fourth of July outing.
photos.source: Scanned from 'Images of Friday America: Friday Harbor'. Authors: Mike and Julia Vouri and the San Juan Historical Society and Museum.
photos.notes: Scanned from a book. Name of vessel was omitted.

photos.description: Jean Culver with Carolyn at Pt. Lawrence Lodge.

photos.description: Roche Harbor. The photo that Carolyn has may have details/dates which need to be provided to Jeff. This may be the Customs house where OH Culver served as the customs agent.
photos.source: Framed photo at Carolyn Leonhardt's cabin.

photos.description: The Holen twins in the 18 ft. Reinell. That is their uncle Helmer Holen on the float.
Two of the Reinell rental boats. The one with the Johnson outboard was 18' and always used by the Holen family. The boat behind was one of the 16' Reinells.
Left to right: Cabin 3, the Community Bathhouse, Cabin 2, and Cabin 1. Photo taken from Cabin 4.

Ken Culver climbing the fir tree. On the ground Dwight Reed and John Willis. Plaid shirt person unknown. Carroll Culver hired a logger to trim limbs and fall several trees on the side of the knoll behind his planned retirement home at Shorewood, Orcas Island. Ken wanted to learn to use the climbing spikes and harness. Once was enough.

Floats at Pt. Lawrence Lodge on a calm summer day. The boat on the left was the 14 foot utility runabout I describe in my separate narrative on 'The Boats in my Life' on this website. The decline of the resort had already begun here - the large float was not put in the water this year and I don't believe it ever was again.
Ken and 'Sea Sled'. See separate article entitled 'The Boats in my Life' written by Ken Culver.

We learned to make dock starts to avoid getting into that cold Rosario Strait's water. As our skills improved we could also make dock landings. Properly performed you skied up close to the float, let go of the ski pull handle, and as you slowed and started to sink you swung your rump around and just sat down on the dock. Barely got wet! (unless you fell while skiing!)

Ken looks like a disaster in the making here, but in reality he and his friends perfected the art of dock starts and landings. That is the ski tow handle splashing on Ken's left. In later years with larger hp motors we learned to single ski and never looked back. We got to the point where we could do a step start by standing on the float and jumping off as the boat pulled us up.
Ken getting up on plane after a dock start.
Another image of a dock landing as performed by Ken Culver. See full description in image 0504.

The beginning of the single ski era! We began by learning to lift one ski out of the water. Once we were comfortable with that we learned to put a single ski on our 'skiing foot' and one of the old double skis on the other. We would start out on two and ultimately drop the old double ski and ski the rest of the ride on one. Single skiing was vastly better. You could ski in rougher water, cut corners like a snow skier, and even jump the boat's wake. In later years, and more powerful boats, we could jump from one side of the wake to the other and reach down and touch the tip of the ski before landing. This could also result in a spectacular crash. Fortunately in those years our bodies were made of rubber and nobody ever got hurt.

Nice late spring day at Pt. Lawrence Lodge. Waterfall still going strong, and floats not in the water. I believe they were not launched this year as Carroll was totally involved in building his retirement home at Shorewood. The white pickup down at the platform was Carroll's 1959 Ford Pickup.
A late spring or early summer visit to Pt. Lawrence. Ken came by boat (not shown).
Ken heading back to Anacortes in his inboard ski boat 'Circe'. Taken by Carroll.
